A comparative study of zirconia and yttria promoted mesoporous carbon-nickel-cobalt catalysts in steam reforming of ethanol for hydrogen production Vahid Shahed Gharahshiran Mardali Yousefpour * Vahid Amini Faculty of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran Faculty of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering Semnan University Semnan Iran Faculty of Metallurgy and Materials Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan, Iran ⁎ Corresponding author at: Faculty of Material and Metallurgical Engineering, Semnan University, Semnan-Damghan Road, Semnan 19111-35131, Iran. Faculty of Material and Metallurgical Engineering Semnan University Semnan-Damghan Road Semnan 19111-35131 Iran Graphical abstract Steam reforming of ethanol process was evaluated over unpromoted / yttria and zirconia-promoted mesoporous carbon-Ni-Co catalysts. The nickel and cobalt ions were added during the synthesis of mesoporous carbon support and then yttrium and zirconium promoters loaded by the wet impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, HR-TEM, TPR, TG-DTA, and FE-SEM methods. XRD and HR-TEM results indicated that the yttria-promoted MC-Ni-Co catalyst has a smaller particle size (the higher dispersion) compared to zirconia-promoted MC-Ni-Co catalyst. Furthermore, TPR analysis confirmed an easier reduction of oxide nanoparticles in the yttria-promoted catalyst compared to the zirconia-promoted catalyst. By adding promoters, the activity of catalysts increased significantly. The catalytic activity of yttria-promoted catalyst (ethanol conversion ̴ 56% at 375 °C) was higher than zirconia-promoted catalyst (ethanol conversion ̴ 46% at 375 °C). Also, it was revealed that increasing the feed ratio could improve catalytic activity. FE-SEM and HR-TEM images indicated the deposited carbon with the filamentous nature on the surface of spent catalysts. The TG analysis showed the highest and lowest amount of carbon deposition for the unpromoted and zirconia-promoted catalysts after the stability test, respectively. Keywords Mesoporous carbon Ethanol steam reforming Ni-Co catalyst Y2O3 promoter ZrO2 promoter Introduction Hydrogen is classified as a potential fuel and energy carrier. A considerable amount of hydrogen is provided from fossil fuels such as coal, natural gas and naphtha [1]. Nowadays, hydrogen production technology by steam reforming and renewable sources is a vital phenomenon [2]. The ethanol production from biomass gives advantages, such as high hydrogen value, low-cost, non-toxicity, easy accessibility, and storage [3]. Because of these advantages, the production of hydrogen from ethanol is economical and eco-friendly [4,5]. In this context, the Steam Reforming of Ethanol (SRE) is a suitable process for hydrogen production that reduces environmental problems and also is thermodynamically favorable. SRE process is an endothermic reaction; as Eq. (1) indicates. (1) C2H5OH + 3H2O → 2CO2 + 6H2 ΔH°298 K = 174 kJ/mol Also, the SRE is a complex process, which creates a challenge for the design of an effective catalyst [6,7]. Generally, the reported catalysts for SRE can be classified into three types. The first includes oxide catalysts, such as Al2O3, MgO and ZnO [6,8]. The oxide catalyst demonstrates low activity and more intermediate products [9]. The second includes metal-based catalysts, such as Co and Ni [10,11], which are desirable for breaking CC bonds and show high SRE performance; but their stability is not proper due to the agglomeration and sintering of active sites [12,13]. The third includes noble metal catalysts, such as Pd, Ir, Rh, Au and Ru [14,15], which have high catalytic performance in the SRE process; but are not economical and usually sinter at high temperatures [16]. Therefore, the nickel and cobalt-based catalysts are appropriate as low-cost non-noble metal catalysts. Ni-based catalyst has high activity for breaking the CC bond of ethanol and hydrogen production during SRE [6,9]. Also, a Co-based catalyst has considerable activity for breaking the CC bond and the creation of the Water Gas Shift (WGS) reaction at low temperatures. The critical problem of Ni and Co-based catalysts is their low stability due to carbon deposition, as well as the agglomeration and sintering of active sites. Following ways have been reported to overcome carbon deposition: (1) Adding promoters [17,18] (2) Utilize different catalytic supports [19,20] (3) Utilize bimetallic catalysts [20,21] (4) Various preparation methods (5) Good dispersion of active sites. Researchers stated that support materials play a vital role in catalytic performance. Utilizing supports with the high surface area may create more dispersion of active sites on the support pores. In this context, the mesostructure materials as catalytic support showed desirable properties [22]. Among them, the mesoporous carbon is known as proper support in embedding nanoparticles due to its high volume and surface area, which can improve hydrogen production in SRE [23]. Lu et al. [24] investigated ordered mesoporous carbon/cobalt composite as a catalyst and magnetically separable adsorbent. Adding metallic ions as promoters, e.g. Y, La, Zr, Ce, Ru and etc. into the mesoporous structure is one of the considerable methods to create active sites [25,26]. These metals have been used to improve the catalytic activity and decreasing carbon deposition [27]. Taherian et al. [28] investigated the catalytic performance of Ni and Co/SBA-15 catalysts with the Sm2O3 promoter in the CO2- reforming. In addition, they investigated Ni/SBA-15 catalyst with ZrO2, Y2O3 and Sm2O3 promoters in dry reforming of methane [29]. They indicated that the Sm2O3-promoted Ni/SBA-15 catalyst had the best catalytic activity compared to others. Nowadays, it is stated that the bimetallic catalyst is proper for improving the anti-carbon deposition and anti-sintering of active sites during the SRE process. Cu-Ni/SiO2 catalyst indicated better anti-carbon deposition compared to Ni/SiO2 catalyst due to adding the copper promoter which prevented carbon deposition [3]. Because of the considerable effects of Ni and Co-based catalysts in SRE, the combination of them can provide high catalytic performance [30]. Co-Ni/hydrotalcite bimetallic catalyst indicated better sintering suppression due to the addition of cobalt which enhanced nickel dispersion [31]. Wang et al. [19] evaluated Ni-Co bimetallic catalyst supported on perovskite-type oxide during SRE reaction and stated that the ethanol conversion was nearly 45% at 400 °C. Busca et al. [32] investigated Ni-Co-Zn-Al catalyst in the SRE process and indicated that the ethanol conversion occurred completely at 500 °C. We have previously investigated the synthesis of Ordered Mesoporous Carbon (OMC)-Ni-Co catalyst with different amounts of Zr promoter (0.5, 1 and 2 wt. %) and was found that OMC-Ni-Co/2 Zr catalyst has better performance than other catalysts in SRE reaction due to the higher dispersion and smaller size of nanoparticles [20]. Since the amorphous carbon has a limitation on increasing the temperature above 400 °C, we could achieve a high hydrogen yield (approximately 75%) at lower temperatures (375 °C) compared to other studied articles. Also, we have used OMC material as new support, which showed good results at low temperatures in the SRE reaction. In addition, its synthesis method was simple and economical. In this study, we have used yttrium as another promoter and focused on the effect of the yttrium promoter on the physicochemical properties of the MC-Ni-Co catalyst and its catalytic performance in the SRE reaction compared to zirconia promoter. In order to do a better comparison between both promoters; the calcined, reduced and spent catalysts were characterized. The catalysts were evaluated in different temperatures and feed ratios, as well as a stability test for 12 h. The physical and chemical properties of calcined catalysts were investigated by BET, XRD, HR-TEM, H2-TPR tests. Also, in this paper, we have studied the nature of deposited carbon over the spent unpromoted / promoted MC-Ni-Co catalysts by TG-DTA and FE-SEM methods. In addition, the structure and morphology of spent promoted MC-Ni-Co catalysts were investigated by XRD and HR-TEM techniques. Experimental Materials Nickel(II) nitrate (Ni(NO3)2.6H2O), Cobalt(II) nitrate (Co(NO3)2.6H2O), Zirconium(IV) oxynitrate hydrate (ZrO(NO3)2.xH2O), Yttrium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Y(NO3)3.6H2O) salts and Resorcinol and Formaldehyde were used as Nickel, Cobalt, Zirconium, Yttrium and Carbon resources, respectively. Pluronic F127 (Mw = 12,600 g/mol, PEO106-PPO70-PEO106) (Sigma-Aldrich) and Sodium hydroxide pellets (NaOH) were utilized as a template and pH controller, respectively. Also, Ethanol absolute was applied as a solvent. Synthesis procedure Mesoporous Carbon (MC)-nickel-cobalt catalyst was synthesized by the hydrothermal method as investigated by Dia et al. [33]. The synthesis details are as follows: initially, 1.3 g of resorcinol was dissolved in a beaker containing 20.8 g of pure ethanol. Then, 0.04 g of sodium hydroxide was dissolved in the as-prepared solution and 2.9 g of formaldehyde was added and stirred for 30 min in order to obtain a homogeneous transparent solution. At the same time, 2.6 g of the F127 template was dissolved in 15.6 g of ethanol at 30 °C in another beaker and then 0.3 g of nickel and 0.3 g of cobalt nitrates were dissolved into this solution. Subsequently, the first solution was added dropwise to the solution containing the F127 template. After titration, the solution was stirred at 25 °C for 2 h, then was kept at 25 °C for 24 h in order to evaporate ethanol, followed by heating in an oven at 110 °C for 24 h. Finally, the prepared catalyst was carbonized in the Ar atmosphere at 700 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 1.5 °C/min. The produced catalyst hereafter is abbreviated as MC-Ni-Co. The wet impregnation method was utilized for promoters loading (2 wt. % Zr and Y) into the bimetallic catalyst supported on MC. Briefly, 1 g of MC-Ni-Co catalyst was dispersed in 100 ml of distilled water and then a proper amount of metal salt was added. The solutions were stirred at 25 °C for 24 h to prepare the MC-Ni-Co/Zr and MC-Ni-Co/Y catalysts. Afterward, these mixtures were filtered and washed with distilled water several times and then the samples were dried in an oven at 100 °C for 3 h. Finally, the catalysts were calcined at 300 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The synthesis strategy of catalysts is shown in Fig. 1 . Characterization Structural properties of fresh and spent catalysts were obtained by BEL sorp mini-II gas adsorption at 77 K. Initially, the prepared samples were pre-treated under the N2 atmosphere at 150 °C for 2 h. The specific surface area was determined using the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) equation in a relative pressure range between P/P° = 0.05–0.3 and the pore size distribution was estimated by BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) method. X-ray patterns of fresh and spent samples were investigated by a Bruker D8 diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (30 mA, 40 kV, and 0.06°/min). The average crystallite size of nanoparticles was calculated by the Scherer equation. The nanoparticles distribution was characterized by a High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HR-TEM, PHILIPS-CM3U) considering accelerating voltages of 150 kV. Initially, the samples were dispersed in the ethanol solution by ultrasonic for 15 min. Temperature Programmed Reduction (TPR) test was carried out for evaluating prepared samples reduction with micro metrics TPD/TPR 2000 gas-adsorption equipment. To do this analysis, a 50 mg sample was heated under the He atmosphere at 300 °C for 1.5 h. Then, it was treated from 100 °C to 750 °C under a mixture of 5H2:95Ar gas flow. The H2 uptake amount was determined using a Thermal Conductivity Detector (TCD). Also, the ramp rate and gas flow were 10 °C/min and 40 ml/min in all steps of the TPR test, respectively. Thermal analysis including Differential Thermal Analysis (DTA) and Thermogravimetry (TG) was carried out using a Linseis L70/2171 from Germany. The catalyst was placed into the thermo-balance and was heated from 25 °C to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C /min under the oxidative atmosphere. In order to evaluate the deposited carbon on the spent catalyst surface, a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM, MIRA3-TESCAN) was used. Catalytic evaluation SRE process was used for investigating catalytic performance. Initially, the samples were pressed, crushed and sieved to 40–60 mesh particles. Afterward, 0.2 g of granule was located into a quartz tubular fixed-bed continuous flow microreactor and the catalytic activity of samples was investigated at different temperatures (200 to 400 °C) and 1 atm pressure. Prior to the test, the samples were reduced at 350 °C for 90 min under a pure H2 flow (25 ml.min−1). The chemical properties of carbon support can be strongly modified by H2 treatment [34]. Therefore, the catalytic activity and stability of carbon support can be improved with H2 treatment. In order to investigate the temperature effect, the catalysts were cooled to 200 °C under N2 flow. Then, as a reactant, a gas mixture (H2O + EtOH + Ar) with a flow rate of 25 ml/min including a vaporized solution (H2O + EtOH) at 140 °C with the molar ratio of water to ethanol of 3:1 was fed into the reactor through pumping. The Gas Hourly Space Velocity (GHSV) of feed was approximately 15 Lgcat −1 h−1. In order to study the effect of feed ratio, the same gases were used in different molar ratios of water to ethanol of 3:1, 6:1 and 12:1 at 375 °C. The feed gas (H2O and EtOH) and products (H2, CO2, CO, and CH4) were characterized using a gas chromatograph equipped with a TCD and a carboxen 1000 column. The product distribution was based on the molar fraction. The ethanol conversion, the selectivity of carbon-containing products, hydrogen yield, and carbon balance were calculated by Eqs. (2), (3), (4) and (5), respectively. (2) X E t h ( % ) = F E t h , i n − F E t h , o u t F E t h , i n × 100 (3) S C i ( % ) = F C i n C i × ( F E t h , i n − F E t h , o u t ) × 100 (4) Y H 2 ( % ) = F H 2 6 × F E t h , i n × 100 (5) C a r b o n − b a l a n c e ( % ) = C H 4 + C O 2 + C O + 2 × C 2 H 4 + 2 × C 2 H 4 O + 2 × E t h o u t 2 × E t h i n × 100 F E t h , i n and F E t h , o u t represent molar flow rates of ethanol at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively. Also, FCi and nCi are the molar flow rate of carbon-containing products and stoichiometric factor between ethanol and carbon-containing products, respectively. F H 2 is the molar flow rate of hydrogen. The carbon balance was calculated based on product output percentage. Results and discussion Characterization of fresh catalysts To investigate the structural and textural properties of fresh catalysts, BET, XRD, HR-TEM, and TPR techniques were used. The promoter type effect on the structural properties of catalysts was investigated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms. The isotherms and pore size distributions of the calcined and reduced catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 a, c and b, d respectively. It is clear that the isotherms of all samples are IV-type with an H2-type hysteresis loop, which according to the IUPAC classification confirm the mesoporous structure with cage-like channels. The isotherms type has not changed by adding various promoters. Previously, similar results with different amounts of nickel in the Ni-OMC catalyst were observed, which suggested cage-like pores into the mesoporous structure [35]. The structural properties of the unpromoted/Y2O3 and ZrO2-promoted catalysts were summarized in Table 1 . As can be seen in Table 1, the presence of a promoter can directly affect the specific surface area, volume, and pores diameter. In addition, the structural properties can change with the type of promoter. According to reviews [36,37], the ion binding method can affect the dispersion of nanoparticles on support. Since in this work, the nickel and cobalt salts were loaded during the synthesis of the carbon support, so the Ni and Co nanoparticles are inside the support structure. In addition, the wet impregnation method was used for promoters loading, which can lead to filling the majority of meso and micropores (which is seen from HR-TEM images). The promoter addition may block the support pores and decrease the nitrogen adsorption, which leads to the decline of the hysteresis loop width. Therefore, it can be seen in Fig. 1a that the hysteresis loop width has increased slightly by adding Zr promoter, which showed a very low increase in pores volume. As can be seen in Table 1, the pore volume has stayed almost constant. Also, the specific surface area has increased by adding Zr promoter, which was due to locating promoter nanoparticles on the support surface. On the other hand, the hysteresis loop width has decreased with the addition of Y promoter, which indicated the filling pores and decreasing the pore volume. Also, the specific surface area has increased slightly by adding the Y2O3 promoter. This phenomenon states that the majority of Y2O3 nanoparticles were loaded inside the support pores and a low amount of promoter has been located on the support surface [38]. Therefore, the specific surface area and pore volume in the catalyst containing the ZrO2 promoter are higher than the catalyst with the Y2O3 promoter. According to Fig. 1b, the distribution profile related to the Y2O3-promoted catalyst was shifted slightly to left compared to the ZrO2-promoted catalyst and the intensity of profile has reduced, which showed the smaller pore diameter and lower pore volume for Y2O3-promoted catalyst compared to ZrO2-promoted catalyst, respectively. The isotherms and pore size distributions of the reduced catalysts are also shown in Fig. 1c and d. The reduced catalysts isotherms are IV-type with an H2-type hysteresis loop similar to the calcined catalysts, which confirm the mesoporous structure. For both the calcined and reduced catalysts, the hysteresis loops were formed at a low P/P° value that stated the small mesopores. The specific surface area of the reduced catalysts is lower than the calcined catalysts due to the higher reduction temperature (350 °C) than the calcination temperature (300 °C) [39]. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the unpromoted / promoted catalysts are shown in Fig.3 . A small-angle XRD pattern for Ni-Co catalyst supported on MC is indicated in Fig. 3a. As can be seen in Fig. 3a, there are four peaks of (110), (200), (211) and (220) with the low intensities that determine the support structure. These created peaks prove the 2-dimensional cubic mesoporous structure (Im3m) of MC support that was created during carbonization by carbon wall collapse [40]. The wide-angle XRD patterns for the calcined catalysts are presented in Fig. 3b. In all the calcined samples, a broad peak was created in the range of 2θ = 15-30˚, indicating the amorphous structure of support. In the unpromoted catalyst, the Ni [001–1255] and Co [001–1258] phases have appeared at 2θ = 44.4˚, 51.72˚ and 76.37˚ angles with fcc structures and Fm3m space groups that confirm the formation of nickel and cobalt metals in the MC lattice after carbonization. The diffraction peaks of nickel and cobalt phases were overlapped due to the structural and morphological similarity of Ni and Co metals. Also, the created peak at 2θ = 26.2˚ is related to graphitic carbon [08-0415] with the hexagonal structure, which is created due to the adjacency of carbon materials with different metals such as nickel, cobalt, and iron (called graphite structure forming metals) after carbonization under the neutral atmosphere [41]. By adding promoters to MC-Ni-Co catalyst, NiO phase at 2θ = 36.9˚, 43.3˚ and 63.7˚ angles with fcc structure and Fm3m space group [44–1159] and Co3O4 phase at 2θ = 36.9˚, 59.5˚ and 65.2˚ angles with fcc structure and Fm3m space group [01–1152] were formed after calcination at 300 °C. As can be seen in Fig. 3b, by adding promoters no significant peak related to Zr, Y, ZrO2, and Y2O3 phases was appeared in the structure due to the low amount or good distribution of promoters on the support. The average crystallite size of nanoparticles was calculated by the Scherer equation and the results are presented in Table 1. The calculations have stated that the average crystallite size of nanoparticles in the promoted catalysts was smaller than unpromoted catalyst, indicating that the addition of promoters had ameliorated the dispersion of nickel and cobalt nanoparticles on the support. Also, the average crystallite size of nanoparticles in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is smaller than ZrO2-promoted catalyst. Thus, Y2O3 promoter has well improved the dispersion of the nanoparticles on the support compared to ZrO2 promoter and can prevent the agglomeration of nanoparticles during SRE process. In addition, Liu et al. [42] observed that the adjacency of yttrium and samarium ions with the nickel ion could reduce the acidity of support surface (increasing the oxygen vacancies) and improved the catalyst performance. Therefore, the promoter next to the improvement of active sites (Ni and Co) dispersion may also have another positive effect on the structure. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the reduced catalysts at 350 °C are shown in Fig. 3c. The reduced catalysts XRD patterns have shown the presence of the Ni and Co metals. As can be seen in Fig. 3c, all the metal oxides were reduced to metal species during reduction. As can be seen in Table 1, the average crystallite size of the nickel and cobalt nanoparticles were bigger in the reduced catalysts compared to the calcined catalysts due to the higher reduction temperature (350 °C) than the calcination temperature (300 °C) [39]. In order to study the mesoporous carbon structure and the dispersion of nanoparticles inside and on the support in the calcined catalysts, HR-TEM micrographs are presented in Fig. 4 . The mesopores are clear in all micrographs, which confirm the mesostructure. It is known by micrographs that the mesostructure of MC has not changed even after several calcinations and impregnations. The micrographs have indicated that metallic salts loading during the synthesis of mesoporous support was a desirable method for good dispersion of nanoparticles inside the structure. Also, good dispersion of nanoparticles was observed even after the addition of promoters by wet impregnation method on the surface and MC walls. As can be seen in Fig. 4, the dispersion of nanoparticles in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is better than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst so that the nanoparticles are agglomerated in some areas in the ZrO2-promoted catalyst (black large spherical nanoparticles). Therefore, it is expected that the catalytic performance of the Y2O3-promoted catalyst will be more desirable than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. According to the micrographs of the Y2O3-promoted catalyst, meso and micro-pores were filled by the Y2O3 promoter and the volume of pores has decreased. These results are in agreement with XRD and BET. The TPR graphs of the unpromoted / promoted catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . In promoted catalysts, one broad peak in the temperature range of 250−450 °C with maxima at 380 °C is related to the reduction of nickel oxide (NiO → Ni) and cobalt oxide (Co3O4 → CoO → Co) nanoparticles, which have a poor interaction with carbon support and reduce easily to the nickel and cobalt metals [43]. The reduction peaks of nickel and cobalt oxides were overlapped on each other in the temperature range of 250−450 °C and have formed a broad peak. In this temperature range, the cobalt oxide nanoparticles were reduced to the cobalt metallic nanoparticles by two-step reduction processes (Co3O4 → CoO → Co). The first (Co3+ → Co2+) and second (Co2+ → Co°) reduction processes have probably occurred in the ranges of 250−350 °C and 350−450 °C, respectively [44]. There is another broad peak in the range of 460−660 °C, which is related to the methanation reaction of carbon support [45]. In addition, the reduction of nickel and cobalt oxides, which provided a stronger interaction with the carbon support occurred probably in this temperature range. Also, the peaks corresponding to the reduction of yttria and zirconia nanoparticles were probably created in the range of 500−520 °C, which overlapped by the methanation peak [46]. As can be seen in Fig. 5, the peaks related to the Y2O3-promoted catalyst with lower intensity are in lower temperatures compared to the ZrO2-promoted catalyst, which indicate easier reducibility of oxide nanoparticles in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst compared to the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. In the unpromoted catalyst, there is no reduction peak related to the oxide nanoparticles due to the calcination of the sample under a neutral atmosphere. Also, this issue was confirmed by the XRD pattern of the calcined unpromoted catalyst, so that there was no peak corresponding to the oxide nanoparticles. Only one broad peak is created in the temperature range of 480−660 °C related to the methanation reaction of the carbon support. Catalytic evaluation The catalytic activity was investigated for the unpromoted / promoted catalysts with the feed molar ratio of 3 at the temperature range of 200−400 °C and 1 atm pressure. According to previous studies, the active sites of nickel could enhance the methane selectivity by breaking CC bonds. Also, the active sites of Co accelerated the dehydrogenation of ethanol and the creation of the water-gas shift reaction at low temperatures [47]. Hence, the ethanol was dehydrogenated to acetaldehyde on an active site of Co, and then acetaldehyde was decomposed to the products on an active site of Ni [48]. It can be noticed that breaking CC bonds in acetaldehyde is easier than CC bonds in the ethanol. Fig. 6 shows the catalytic performance of the unpromoted / promoted catalysts. The catalytic performance of the unpromoted catalyst is weak. Decreasing the ethanol conversion above 300 °C is due to the sintering and agglomeration of active sites on the support. By the addition of promoters, the initial temperature of ethanol conversion in the promoted catalysts (250 °C) has decreased compared to the unpromoted catalyst (300 °C). The catalytic activity of the samples containing promoter is higher than the unpromoted catalyst due to the presence of promoter nanoparticles and their positive effect on the structural properties of catalysts. In addition, the catalytic performance of the yttria-promoted catalyst is higher than the zirconia-promoted catalyst due to the smaller crystallite size of nanoparticles and their higher dispersion on the support. The initial temperature of ethanol conversion in the zirconia-promoted catalyst is above 250 °C, while in the yttria-promoted catalyst is above 200 °C. Also, the highest value of ethanol conversion in the zirconia-promoted catalyst is 46%, while in the yttria-promoted catalyst is approximately 51% at 375 °C. Decreasing the ethanol conversion at temperatures higher than 375 °C may be due to the evaporation of the MC support and the agglomeration of active sites. Generally, the reaction of steam reforming of ethanol occurs completely at temperatures above 400 °C, but in this study due to using the amorphous-type carbon support, there was a limitation on increasing the temperature higher than 400 °C. In the unpromoted catalyst, the ethanol was decomposed to acetaldehyde in the first step (Eq. (6)) and then acetaldehyde converted to CH4 and CO (Eq. (7)). At the temperature range of 300−325 °C, the water-gas shift reaction (Eq. (8)) has occurred so that the selectivity of CO decreased and the CO2 selectivity and the H2 yield increased. Subsequently, by increasing the temperature above 325 °C, the CO2 selectivity has reduced and the selectivity of CO and CH4 increased, which confirm Reverse Water-Gas Shift (RWGS) (Eq. (8)) and methanation reaction (Eq. (9)). In the ZrO2-promoted catalyst, the ethanol was dehydrated to acetaldehyde on the Co sites and then acetaldehyde decomposed to methane and CO. In the following, the water-gas reaction took place at the temperature range of 250−300 °C so that the selectivity of CO has decreased and the selectivity of CO2 increased. As a result, the reverse water-gas shift reaction has occurred at the temperature range of 275−300 °C and at above 300 °C, both steam reforming of methane (Eq. (9)) and water-gas shift reactions occurred; hence the selectivity of CH4 and CO have reduced and the selectivity of CO2 increased [49,50]. (6) C2H5OH → CH3CHO + H2 (7) CH3CHO → CH4 + CO (8) CO + H2O ↔ CO2 + H2 (9) CO2 + 4H2 ↔ CH4 + 2H2O In the Y2O3-promoted catalyst, the ethanol was decomposed to acetaldehyde and then acetaldehyde converted to CO and methane. Increasing the CO2 selectivity and decreasing the CO selectivity at the temperature range of 200−275 °C was due to the water-gas shift reaction. At the temperature range of 275−325 °C, the RWGS and steam reforming of methane reactions were carried out. The methanation and WGS reactions have also occurred at the temperature range of 325−350 °C and at above 350 °C, the steam reforming of methane and WGS reactions took place. The hydrogen yield and selectivity of CO2 were higher and lower in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst compared to the ZrO2-promoted at high temperatures, respectively. In order to optimize the catalytic performance, the promoted catalysts were evaluated in the feed molar ratios of 3, 6 and 12. Fig. 7 A shows the ethanol conversion in different S/E ratios for the promoted catalysts at 375 °C and GHSV = 15 L gcat −1  h−1. As it is clear, the feed ratio in the SRE process is a vital factor so that in the higher feed ratios than stoichiometric coefficients of the reaction, the lower amount of carbon deposits on active sites [51]. Fig. 7A shows that the ethanol conversion for both catalysts has increased with increasing the feed ratio. Also, the ethanol conversion in all feed ratios for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is higher than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst due to the better influence of the yttria promoter on active sites of Ni and Co compared to zirconia promoter. The amount difference of the ethanol conversion from the feed ratio of 6–12 for both promoted catalysts has achieved more than 20%. In addition, increasing the feed ratio also affects the selectivity of by-products and main products. As shown in Fig. 7B, the hydrogen yield has increased with increasing the feed ratio, which was in agreement with previous works [52,53]. Also, the hydrogen yield in all feed ratios for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is higher than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. In addition, the CO2 selectivity has increased with increasing the feed ratio so that the CO2 selectivity for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst was lower than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. The lower amount of CO2 is more suitable in the SRE process since it can easily be removed by the photosynthesis of plants [54]. As can be seen in Fig. 7B, the CH4 selectivity for both promoted catalysts has decreased with increasing the feed ratio. Also, the selectivity of CO for both promoted catalysts has reduced with increasing the feed ratio from 3 to 6. The selectivity of CO for the ZrO2-promoted catalyst has increased slightly and it for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst has not changed with increasing the feed ratio from 6–12. The lowest CO content is suitable for the SRE process because it is a by-product of the reaction and can poison the metal active sites. Therefore, the highest ethanol conversion and hydrogen yield have obtained in the higher feed ratios. As a result, the Y2O3-promoted catalyst has a better catalytic performance than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. Bichon et al. [55] evaluated Co/TiO2, Co/SiO2, Co/Al2O3, and Ni/Al2O3 catalysts in SRE process and indicated that the ethanol conversion in all catalysts at 375 °C and the feed molar ratio of 6 was less than 40%; while in our study for the promoted catalysts was approximately 60%. Choong et al. [56] investigated the catalytic performance of the unpromoted / Ca-promoted Ni/Al2O3 catalysts at 400 °C and the feed molar ratio of 10 for 24 h. As was found, the catalytic performance reduced after several hours in the feed molar ratio of 10 due to the blocking active sites by carbon deposition. Also, in our work, the unpromoted catalyst was deactivated after 5 h by coke deposition on the active sites in the feed molar ratio of 12. Thus, several previous studies [57–59] tested the catalytic performance in the high feed ratios and it was found that the catalysts could also be deactivated in the high feed ratios due to the coke deposition. However, in our study, the promoted catalysts have remained active in the feed molar ratio of 12 even after 12 h. Also, Chiou et al. [50] investigated the performance of Pt-promoted cobalt-based catalysts in steam reforming of ethanol at low temperatures and feed molar ratios of 3-13. It was found that catalysts had the best performance with the feed molar ratio of 13. As can be seen in Fig. 7B, the selectivity of CO2, CO, and CH4 for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst in the feed molar ratio of 12 were lower than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. In addition, the carbon balance (Eq. (5)) related to gases for both promoted catalysts was indicated in Fig. 7C. According to Fig. 7C, the carbon balance for the ZrO2-promoted catalyst is higher than the Y2O3-promoted catalyst in all feed ratios. In order to evaluate the stability of the unpromoted / promoted catalysts in the SRE reaction, the catalysts were investigated in the feed molar ratio of 12, GHSV = 15 L gcat −1  h−1 and the optimum temperature (375 °C). The results are based on product output percentage and are shown in Fig. 8 . As was illustrated in Fig. 8, the unpromoted / promoted catalysts were evaluated for 12 h during the SRE reaction. The promoted catalysts have exhibited the proper stability due to the presence of promoter nanoparticles and their positive effect on the structural properties of catalysts. On the other hand, the unpromoted catalyst has shown the poor stability for 5 h with low ethanol conversion and then was deactivated due to the sintering and agglomeration of nanoparticles on the support and the formation of coke on active sites. According to Fig. 8, the Y2O3-promoted catalyst has shown better catalytic activity compared to the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. Gayubo et al. [60] evaluated the Ni/LaAL catalyst in the feed molar ratio of 6 for SRE reaction so that the results showed that the hydrogen yield was approximately 45% at 500 °C; while in our study for both promoted catalysts in the same feed ratio was approximately 45% at 375 °C. In addition, Chiou et al. [50] evaluated the catalytic performance of Pt-promoted cobalt-based catalysts in SRE reaction and the results showed that the distribution of hydrogen was approximately 65%, while in our work for Y2O3-promoted catalyst was approximately 80% during the stability test. In the SRE reaction, the carbon with different natures can precipitate on the catalyst surface. The nature of deposited carbon is one of the vital factors which can greatly affect the activity of active sites. The two types of carbon such as amorphous and filamentous carbons may precipitate during the process. During the SRE reaction, the coke (amorphous carbon) is produced by the decomposition of ethylene and filamentous carbon is formed by methane decomposition (Eq. (10)) or Boudouard reaction (Eq. (11)). In addition, ethylene can be produced by the sequential dehydrogenation of methane at temperatures above 300 °C (Eq. (12)) (Eq. (13)) [50]. On the other hand, the selectivity of ethylene decreases significantly with increasing the feed ratio [43]. Since in this study the temperature of the catalytic performance is below 400 °C, it is possible to ignore the Boudouard reaction. The main reason for the filamentous carbon formation in this study is the decomposition of methane. (10) CH4 → 2H2 + C (11) 2CO → CO2 + C (12) CH4 → CH3 → CH2 (13) 2CH2 → C2H4 Characterization of spent catalysts In order to show the structural properties of spent catalysts and the deposited carbon nature on the catalyst surface, XRD, TG-DTA, FE-SEM, and HR-TEM analyses were utilized. The content and nature of deposited carbon on the unpromoted and promoted catalysts were evaluated by TG-DTA analysis and the results are shown in Fig. 9 . The TG curve shows the percentage of weight loss relative to the deposited carbon oxidation. The TG analysis has confirmed that the highest percentage of weight loss was related to the unpromoted catalyst; while the lowest percentage of weight loss was related to the ZrO2-promoted catalyst that these results are in agreement with carbon balance results. In addition, DTA profiles were used for investigating the nature of deposited carbon. In the unpromoted catalyst, there are two sharp peaks at about 350 °C and 500 °C, which show different nature of the deposited carbon on the catalyst surface. Djinovic P et al. [61] also examined two peaks at about 300 °C and 550 °C for Ni-Co catalyst, which were related to various carbon species. The exothermic peak at about 300 °C is related to the amorphous type carbon and the endothermic peak at about 550 °C is related to the fibrous type carbon. The amorphous carbon sticks on active sites and blocks them and prevents the adsorption of feed steam on metal active sites. Therefore, the main reason for the rapid deactivation of the unpromoted catalyst after 5 h is the deposition of amorphous type carbon during the stability test on active sites. Since in this study the catalytic support is amorphous type carbon, so the oxidation of catalytic support is also overlapped with the peak at about 300 °C. In the promoted catalysts, two weak exothermic peaks in the temperature range of 300−350 °C are related to the amorphous type carbon, which are created due to oxidation of the catalytic support. In the promoted catalysts, an exothermic peak at 500 °C was also created due to the presence of filamentous carbon, which was weaker in the ZrO2-promoted catalyst than the Y2O3-promoted catalyst. FE-SEM images of the unpromoted and promoted catalysts after the stability test are shown in Fig. 10 . As it is clear in Fig. 10, the filamentous carbon was deposited on the surface of all samples. As can be seen in Fig. 10, a low amount of filamentous carbon and more amounts of amorphous carbon (sticky) have deposited on the surface of the unpromoted catalyst so that surrounded the active sites and deactivated the catalyst. In the ZrO2-promoted catalyst, the dispersion of nickel and cobalt nanoparticles has reduced and the nanoparticles were agglomerated in some regions (white regions). In the Y2O3-promoted catalyst even after the stability test, the nanoparticles of nickel and cobalt have retained their dispersion and were distributed throughout the structure. This issue state that the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is a promising catalyst in the SRE reaction. Zhang et al. [62] and Djinovic et al. [61] also reported that the filamentous carbons grow around the nickel nanoparticles by diffusion of carbon and the nickel particles locate on their top. Therefore, the nanoparticles have placed on the top of fibers and the fibers could not surround the nanoparticles in the promoted catalysts. It is seen that the diameter of a large number of fibers in the promoted catalysts is in the range of 20−70 nm. These results are in agreement with TG-DTA results. XRD analysis was performed over the spent catalysts and the patterns are shown in Fig. 11 . In all spent catalysts, no significant peak related to metal oxides was seen, proving that the nanoparticles have remained metallic in all reaction steps. The intensity of the peak at 2θ = 26.2˚ that is related to graphite carbon for the unpromoted catalyst is lower, while the intensity of the broad peak in the range of 15-30˚ that is corresponding to amorphous material is higher than the promoted catalysts owing to the more carbon deposition with amorphous nature during the reaction. On the other hand, the intensity of the graphite peak for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is higher than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst due to the more presence of filamentous carbon on the Y2O3-promoted catalyst. These results are in agreement with TG-DTA and FESEM results. As can be seen in Table 1, the average crystallite size of nanoparticle in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst is smaller than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst, which indicates the more sintering and agglomeration of Ni and Co nanoparticles during the stability test in the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. Also, the average crystallite size of nanoparticle in the unpromoted catalyst has increased after the stability test. In order to prove the filamentous type carbon and the presence of nickel and cobalt nanoparticles on the top of these fibers, HR-TEM micrographs were taken for the Y2O3-promoted catalyst and are shown in Fig. 12 . As it is clear in Fig. 12, the nanoparticles have located on top of fibers and were not surrounded by fibers. Thus, it could be concluded that the nanoparticles were in contact with the feed stream during the stability test and have remained active. Conclusion The catalysts with yttria and zirconia promoters were successfully synthesized by the wet impregnation method and evaluated during the SRE process. The results revealed that the addition of promoters could greatly improve the structural properties of catalysts and have a positive effect on catalytic activity. Therefore, the smallest crystallite size of nanoparticles (the highest dispersion) obtained in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst (according to XRD and HR-TEM results). According to the TPR analysis, the reducibility of oxide nanoparticles in the Y2O3-promoted catalyst was easier than the ZrO2-promoted catalyst. By studying the SRE process conditions, it was found that the catalytic performance improved with increasing the feed ratio. The most amount of carbon was deposited on the unpromoted catalyst during the stability test, which was confirmed by TG analysis. The main reason for poor performance and deactivation of the unpromoted catalyst after 5 h was the deposition of amorphous type carbon (sticky) on active sites and blocking them. The amount of deposited carbon on the ZrO2-promoted catalyst was lower than the Y2O3-promoted catalyst and the deposited carbon nature was filamentous. The main reason for the non-deactivation of the promoted catalysts after 12 h was the lack of presence of enclosed nanoparticles by fibers (this is evident by FESEM and HRTEM images). Therefore, the Y promoter had the highest positive effect on catalytic activity in the SRE process. Declaration of Competing Interest None. coredata.dc:description: Steam reforming of ethanol process was evaluated over unpromoted / yttria and zirconia-promoted mesoporous carbon-Ni-Co catalysts. The nickel and cobalt ions were added during the synthesis of mesoporous carbon support and then yttrium and zirconium promoters loaded by the wet impregnation method. The catalysts were characterized by BET, XRD, HR-TEM, TPR, TG-DTA, and FE-SEM methods. XRD and HR-TEM results indicated that the yttria-promoted MC-Ni-Co catalyst has a smaller particle size (the higher dispersion) compared to zirconia-promoted MC-Ni-Co catalyst. Furthermore, TPR analysis confirmed an easier reduction of oxide nanoparticles in the yttria-promoted catalyst compared to the zirconia-promoted catalyst. By adding promoters, the activity of catalysts increased significantly. The catalytic activity of yttria-promoted catalyst (ethanol conversion ̴ 56% at 375 °C) was higher than zirconia-promoted catalyst (ethanol conversion ̴ 46% at 375 °C). Also, it was revealed that increasing the feed ratio could improve catalytic activity. FE-SEM and HR-TEM images indicated the deposited carbon with the filamentous nature on the surface of spent catalysts. The TG analysis showed the highest and lowest amount of carbon deposition for the unpromoted and zirconia-promoted catalysts after the stability test, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: A comparative study of zirconia and yttria promoted mesoporous carbon-nickel-cobalt catalysts in steam reforming of ethanol for hydrogen production
